name: AI Gemini~ OI (G7) - Decontamination Skills and Policy Verification
intro:
Overview of Decontamination Requirements

This questionnaire verifies your understanding of the G7 Decontamination Policy and SOP. It covers operational roles, safety protocols, and the treatment of vulnerable persons during decontamination procedures.

structure.description: According to the policy, who is the agency responsible for the decontamination of the public and personnel at incidents attended by Fire and Emergency New Zealand?
options: Health New Zealand
New Zealand Police
Fire and Emergency New Zealand
Local Authorities

structure.description: Which of the following are principles of decontamination as defined in the G7 policy? (Select all that apply)
options: Timeliness
Effectiveness
Prevent or minimise further harm
Reasonably implementable/achievable
Compulsory enforcement
correctAnswer: Timeliness
Effectiveness
Prevent or minimise further harm
Reasonably implementable/achievable

structure.description: Can Fire and Emergency personnel use force to decontaminate an individual against their will if they believe it is necessary for safety?
What is the minimum flow rate required for emergency decontamination of a person wearing permeable clothing?
options: 200 litres/minute
400 litres/minute
600 litres/minute
100 litres/minute

structure.description: Describe the specific restriction regarding Portaflex showers and their use on infants or members of the public.
structure.correctAnswer: Portaflex showers should not be used on members of the public or infants, nor on personnel who are not wearing non-permeable suits and breathing apparatus.

structure.description: Within what timeframe must a Decontamination Officer record exposure to a hazardous substance in Safe@Work?
options: 12 hours
24 hours
48 hours
7 days

structure.description: When decontaminating a child, what steps must firefighters take to ensure protection and professionalism? (Select all that apply)
options: Only undress or wash a child if a parent/caregiver cannot
Ensure the firefighter is never alone with the child in an enclosed space while undressing
Perform decontamination in total isolation to ensure privacy
Report any suspected child abuse observed during the process
correctAnswer: Only undress or wash a child if a parent/caregiver cannot
Ensure the firefighter is never alone with the child in an enclosed space while undressing
Report any suspected child abuse observed during the process

structure.description: Where should the decontamination facility be located in relation to the incident zones?
options: Deep within the Hot Zone
In the middle of the Cold Zone
At the transition from the Hot Zone to the Cold Zone
At the Fire Station
structure.correctAnswer: At the transition from the Hot Zone to the Cold Zone

name: E3-2 Respiratory Protection
intro: The learning document for this test is at E3-2 Respiratory Protection in the FENZ Portal (requires to login with your FENZ account)

structure.description: Firefighters must don BA before entering a structure to investigate a fire, when must firefighters start up their BA?
options: As soon as they start to smell any smoke
Whenever they are operating in conditions that may expose them to a contaminated atmosphere
Other atmospheres that are irrespirable (e.g. depleted oxygen)
On the instruction of the Pump Operator
As soon as they have entered the building
correctAnswer: Whenever they are operating in conditions that may expose them to a contaminated atmosphere
Other atmospheres that are irrespirable (e.g. depleted oxygen)

structure.description: What equipment must all appliances that carry BA sets also carry?
options: Entry Control Board
Chemical Splash Suits
Entry Control Officer Jerkin
Thermal Image Camera
At least 1 BA Main Guide Line
90m High Pressure Hosereel
correctAnswer: Entry Control Board
Chemical Splash Suits
At least 1 BA Main Guide Line

structure.description: Which pieces of equipment must all BA sets have?
options: Tally
Thermal Image Camera
Torch
Distress Signal Unit (DSU)
Gas detector
Personal Line
Pocket knife
correctAnswer: Tally
Torch
Distress Signal Unit (DSU)
Personal Line

structure.description: The Entry Control Officer (ECO) is responsible for controlling the entry and exit of BA wearers into a hot zone, what other tasks is the ECO responsible for?
options: Monitoring the safety of BA wearers
Tasking and deploying emergency teams as required
Helping to establish water supplies
Ensuring there is a response to any emergency involving BA wearers
Maintaining resources for BA wearers
Recommissioning BA sets ready for use
correctAnswer: Monitoring the safety of BA wearers
Tasking and deploying emergency teams as required
Maintaining resources for BA wearers

structure.description: Which of these would be a requirement for Stage 2 BA Control ?
options: More than 2 Entry Control Points are set up
There are 16 personnel or more on the incident ground
Six or more BA Teams are operating at the same time
Confined space entry
The OIC considers it necessary
There are multiple persons reported missing
correctAnswer: More than 2 Entry Control Points are set up
Six or more BA Teams are operating at the same time
The OIC considers it necessary

structure.description:
In order to avoid leaks around the face mask seal a BA wearer must :
• not grow facial hair around the area of the mask seal.
• not wear glasses that pass through the mask seal .
• comply with manufacturers instructions.
• comply with AS/NZS 1715:2009, (Selection, Use and Maintenance of Respiratory Protective Devices).
Why might a firefighter have a green rectangle marked on their helmet?
options: Aerial appliance operators
Telemetry Set operators
Gas Suit qualified
Medical First Response

name: FL2 Use of FENZ Operational Vehicles
intro: The learning document for this test is at FL2 Use of FENZ Operational Vehicles in the FENZ Portal (requires to login with your FENZ account)

structure.description: When responding to an emergency incident, when must both siren and beacons be used?
options: Whenever the vehicle is moving
When travelling against the traffic, through red lights or stop signs at intersections
When parking at an incident on the wrong side of the road
When requested by FireComms
structure.correctAnswer: When travelling against the traffic, through red lights or stop signs at intersections

structure.description: If a drivers license has been suspended, disqualified or restricted in any way, who must be notified?
options: No one, it's personal information
The Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency
Advise your Chief Fire Officer or Manager
The Police
structure.correctAnswer: Advise your Chief Fire Officer or Manager

structure.description: Under what circumstances can a firefighter drive an ambulance in an emergency situation?
options: Never
When requested by the Ambulance OIC, the driver must have a Class 1 license and have current competency in emergency response driving (ERD).
When directed by your OIC
Only if you have been properly inducted and are familiar with the vehicle
structure.correctAnswer: When requested by the Ambulance OIC, the driver must have a Class 1 license and have current competency in emergency response driving (ERD).

structure.description: What is the maximum permitted speed for a heavy operational vehicle responding under lights and siren on the open road? (Type 1 to 4)
options: 130km/h
105km/h
110km/h
Speed limits do not apply to FENZ vehicles

structure.description: What is the maximum permitted speed in a 50 km/h zone when responding under lights and siren to an emergency?
options: 65 km/h
75 km/h
85 km/h
50 km/h

structure.description: What is the maximum speed limit through a temporary speed zone?
options: 15 km/h above the posted speed limit
Up to 105 km/h if the driver considers it safe
The posted speed limit
25 km/h above the posted speed limit

structure.description: What is the maximum speeds permitted at intersections controlled by lights, stop or give way signs in an emergency response?
options: Up to 105 km/h if the driver considers it safe
As fast as the OIC requests me to go
Slow to 10 km/h and stop if necessary, proceed if the way is clear, at a speed not exceeding 20 km/h and provided siren and beacons are operating
Stop at the lights and wait for the green signal
structure.correctAnswer: Slow to 10 km/h and stop if necessary, proceed if the way is clear, at a speed not exceeding 20 km/h and provided siren and beacons are operating

structure.description: When may the driver of a FENZ vehicle use a handheld cellphone?
options: When it is necessary to speak with FireComms and the LMR is not working
When the vehicle has stopped and parked out of the line of traffic or the call is to 111 or *555 and it unsafe or unpractical to stop and park out of the line of traffic
If trying to find directions to the incident
Never
structure.correctAnswer: When the vehicle has stopped and parked out of the line of traffic or the call is to 111 or *555 and it unsafe or unpractical to stop and park out of the line of traffic

structure.description: What is the maximum number of BA cylinders that may be transported in a FENZ vehicle other than a BA Tender?
options: 12 Cylinders
18 Cylinders
24 Cylinders
28 Cylinders

structure.description: The number of persons permitted to be carried in a FENZ vehicle is 1 person per seat belt provided.
What are the two points mentioned in Driving Policy that relate to the driving of private vehicles to or from the station or incident? (Click all that apply)
options: Personnel must observe the posted road speed limit
Speed limit can be exceeded in an emergency
Personnel are not covered by FENZ for damage or loss to a private vehicle
Seat belts are optional for short distances
Private vehicles can be left on yellow lines when attending an incident
correctAnswer: Personnel must observe the posted road speed limit
Personnel are not covered by FENZ for damage or loss to a private vehicle

name: G2-1 Emergency Medical Support
intro: The learning document for this test is at G2-1 Emergency Medical Support in the FENZ Portal (requires to login with your FENZ account)

structure.description: If a member of Fire and Emergency NZ is injured/unwell when on duty, under the terms of this policy who must be notified by the OIC?
options: Chief Fire Officer / Group Manager
No one, it is up to the injured person to notify the correct people
The person's emergency contact
The Health and Safety Officer
correctAnswer: Chief Fire Officer / Group Manager
The Health and Safety Officer

structure.description: If an on duty member of Fire and Emergency NZ is taken to hospital, what must the OIC ensure takes place?
options: That the injured person remains at work until they are replaced by another person
That they are provided with travel home, including their vehicle
That they are accompanied by a member of Fire and Emergency NZ until handover occurs to the emergency contact or they are discharged and returned home.
Nothing, the injured crew member needs to get themselves to hospital
correctAnswer: That they are provided with travel home, including their vehicle
That they are accompanied by a member of Fire and Emergency NZ until handover occurs to the emergency contact or they are discharged and returned home.

structure.description: At an incident when decontamination is carried out (other than gloves & boots) on people who have no PPE, level 1 or level 2 PPE or compromised level 3 or 4 PPE, what must the OIC ensure is requested?
options: ComCen are advised to request an ambulance
The on-call VSO is to bring replacement clothing, food, and transport the decontaminated people home
A tent so that people can get changed in privacy
structure.correctAnswer: ComCen are advised to request an ambulance

structure.description: What must the OIC ensure happens at an incident if there is an injury to a firefighter or a member of the public or, the incident is lower that 4th alarm but the OIC considers there is a significant risk of injury?
options: Ask the VSO to bring out a first aid kit and a blanket.
OIC must ensure that Comcen requests ambulance response
Request a Health and Safety Officer to attend
structure.correctAnswer: OIC must ensure that Comcen requests ambulance response

name: G7 Decontamination
intro: The learning document for this test is at G7 Decontamination Procedures and G7 Decontamination Policy in the FENZ Portal (requires to login with your FENZ account)

structure.description: Which agency is responsible for the decontamination of members of the public?
options: Police
FENZ
Ambulance Service

structure.description: What must be in place before firefighters enter a hot zone?
options: Preparations for emergency decontamination are in place
Firefighters are wearing barrier gloves and a dust mask.
Consideration has been given to requesting resources for deliberate decontamination
Gas detector has been set up to identify the hazardous material.
Hazardous material has been identified
correctAnswer: Preparations for emergency decontamination are in place
Consideration has been given to requesting resources for deliberate decontamination

structure.description: What other agency may be required to assist with the decontamination of a person who poses a threat to FENZ personnel?
options: Defence Force personnel
Ambulance Service
Police

structure.description: Emergency Decontamination is to be used when there is a need to decontaminate before deliberate decontamination equipment can arrive. eg, medical emergency or life risk.
Emergency Decontamination is to be used when there is a need to decontaminate before deliberate decontamination equipment can arrive. eg, medical emergency or life risk.
options: The personnel to be decontaminated must be wearing BA with a Splash suit, Gas Suit or other agency equivalent.Option 1
Members of the public wearing permeable clothing (liquids/gas can pass through) that has been contaminated.
The personnel to be decontaminated must be wearing a minimum of structure gear and BA
The contaminant must be water-miscible and safely diluted and directed into a drain or sewer.
correctAnswer: The personnel to be decontaminated must be wearing BA with a Splash suit, Gas Suit or other agency equivalent.Option 1
Members of the public wearing permeable clothing (liquids/gas can pass through) that has been contaminated.

structure.description: What factors determine whether the decontamination corridor should be used?
options: People are wearing permeable clothing (liquids/gas can pass through)
FENZ personnel wearing Structural Firefighting PPE
Firefighters in Gas Tight suits that have been contaminated.
There is no Portaflex shower available
The contaminant is immiscible in water (does not mix or dissolve) or there is a need to contain the run-off
correctAnswer: There is no Portaflex shower available
The contaminant is immiscible in water (does not mix or dissolve) or there is a need to contain the run-off

structure.description: Who decides whether the run-off from a decontamination procedure should be contained?
options: Pump operator
OIC
HAZCHEM or specialist advice
Police

structure.description: Which of these are NOT key responsibilities of the Decontamination Officer
options: Managing the decontamination function on the incident ground
Reporting to the Fire Logistics Commander
Ensuring crews have adequate rest and refreshment
Assigning tasks to personnel to assist with the decontamination process
Identifying safety issues and hazards on the incident ground
Ensure all decontamination forms are completed
correctAnswer: Ensuring crews have adequate rest and refreshment
Identifying safety issues and hazards on the incident ground

structure.description:
The OIC HazMat /Command vehicle is responsible for ensuring the safe and appropriate
recommissioning of all decontamination equipment.
Which of these are the OIC Fire’s responsibilities?
options: Ensuring that all SHEP forms are completed during the decontamination process
Ensuring FENZ personnel carrying out decontamination during an incident follow the requirements of the HazMat policy
Appointing a Decontamination Officer whenever the decontamination corridor is in use or as required
Ensuring that the hazardous material is removed from the site to a place of safety
correctAnswer: Ensuring FENZ personnel carrying out decontamination during an incident follow the requirements of the HazMat policy
Appointing a Decontamination Officer whenever the decontamination corridor is in use or as required

name: G9 Salvage
intro: The learning document for this test is at G9 Salvage in the FENZ Portal (requires to login with your FENZ account)

structure.description: The main reason for carrying out salvage operations is to minimise or prevent further loss to property at incidents
When the OIC Fire orders salvage operations to commence, the officer is attempting to reduce damage to property by limiting the damage caused by what factors?
options: Firefighting activities.
Heat and Smoke
Members of the public
Police
Water damage.
Adverse weather.
Clandestine laboratory (ClanLab) operations
correctAnswer: Firefighting activities.
Heat and Smoke
Water damage.
Adverse weather.

structure.description: What methods can be used to reduce damage from sprinkler systems?
options: Turn off sprinkler on arrival
“Sprinkler stoppers”
Floor isolation and main sprinkler valves.
Collect water in buckets
Place absorbent material beneath activated sprinkler heads
correctAnswer: Floor isolation and main sprinkler valves.
Place absorbent material beneath activated sprinkler heads

structure.description: Salvage should be commenced as early as possible at a hazardous substance incidents
Which Fire and Emergency Operational Instructions can be used for hazard control during salvage operations?
options: Operational Safety
Breathing Apparatus
Confined Space
Ventilation
Decontamination
correctAnswer: Ventilation
Decontamination

name: H1-H6 - Hazardous Materials
intro: This questionnaire verifies your knowledge of operational procedures for managing hazardous materials incidents as defined in NCI 21. Refer to the official manual for guidance if needed.

structure.description: Which of these considerations should be taken into account in relation to hazardous material incidents?
options: How to proceed to the incident and deploy resouces safely
PPE and BA
Correct siting of aerial appliances
The isolation and identification of hazardous material(s)
Ensuring crews have enough to eat and drink
Any evacuation required
The protection of the environment.
The closure of FENZ involvement in the incident.
correctAnswer: How to proceed to the incident and deploy resouces safely
PPE and BA
The isolation and identification of hazardous material(s)
Any evacuation required
The protection of the environment.
The closure of FENZ involvement in the incident.

structure.description: Name the primary source of technical information that the FENZ uses for hazardous materials?
What is the system that Fire Comms uses to transmit hazardous material information to the incident ground?
Which of these is NOT one of the seven initial actions to be considered when attending a hazardous materials incident?
options: Only the first appliance should approach and investigate.
Approach from upwind when possible
Park 400m away from incident
Appliances responding later should park clear of the incident.
Wear appropriate PPE.
Appoint a safety officer when a hot zone is identified.
Always use Chemical Splash Suits and BA for snap rescues
Consider greater alarm.
Ensure there are water tankers available for decontamination
Advise other responding appliances and services of the safe approach route
correctAnswer: Park 400m away from incident
Always use Chemical Splash Suits and BA for snap rescues
Ensure there are water tankers available for decontamination

structure.description: Which of the following essential pieces of information could be used to identify hazardous materials?
options: Name (trade, common, chemical).
Manufacturer
Consignee
Colour and smell
UN number
NFPA 704
Details from hazardous goods label
State of material (solid, liquid or gas)
Approximate amount spilled
Flammable range
correctAnswer: Name (trade, common, chemical).
Manufacturer
Consignee
UN number
NFPA 704
Details from hazardous goods label
State of material (solid, liquid or gas)
Approximate amount spilled

structure.description: Which of the following considerations that should be undertaken to ensure an incident is isolated?
options: Evacuate upwind or across wind clear of smoke/fumes
Place Hot Zone tape around the whole incident
Consider in-place protection.
Move all personnel and public downwind of the incident
correctAnswer: Evacuate upwind or across wind clear of smoke/fumes
Consider in-place protection.

structure.description: Which methods could you can use to stop further contamination from a spilled/leaked hazardous material?
options: Turn off valves
Right cylinders or turn leak to its highest point
Channel fluids into nearest drain
Cover spillage or apply a foam blanket if appropriate
Sweep up any dry materials and place in a bag
Contain the spillage by damming
Use a water jet to dilute the materials
correctAnswer: Turn off valves
Right cylinders or turn leak to its highest point
Cover spillage or apply a foam blanket if appropriate
Contain the spillage by damming

structure.description: The statutory powers of FENZ cease in relation to a hazardous material incident when the material has been stabilised and made safe
What actions should be taken when a hazardous material is involved in fire?
options: Contain the fire. Once the hazard level and the hazardous materials are identified, use the appropriate extinguishing medium and PPE
Fall back to a safe distance and use ground monitors to extinguish the fire
Ensure crew are wearing Chemical Splash Suits and approach carefully using the Co-ordinated Water Protection Technique
structure.correctAnswer: Contain the fire. Once the hazard level and the hazardous materials are identified, use the appropriate extinguishing medium and PPE

structure.description: The OIC Fire determines the level of decontamination to be carried out by consulting with the HSTLC, a suitably qualified person, and/or the enforcement officer if further advice is necessary.

name: H5 Bulk Flammable Liquids
intro: This verification questionnaire is based on Operational Instruction NCI 31 for safe and effective operations at incidents involving bulk flammable liquids.

structure.description: Which of these would be operational considerations when dealing with bulk flammable liquids?
options: Pre-determined response and automatic upgrading to a greater alarm
Arresting whoever was responsible for the spillage
Evacuation
Liaison with other organizations
Organising food supplies and refreshments
Water and Foam concentrate supplies
Effect on the environment
Topographical and climatic features
Fast response wearing chemical splash suits
Media statements
correctAnswer: Pre-determined response and automatic upgrading to a greater alarm
Evacuation
Liaison with other organizations
Water and Foam concentrate supplies
Effect on the environment
Topographical and climatic features
Media statements

structure.description: Describe the firefighting considerations for bulk flammable liquids.
options: Extinguishing and/or cooling
Attack fire from upwind
Protecting exposures
Chemical splash suits to avoid contamination
Extinguishing ground fires before attacking the contents of a tank
Approach fire from a downhill position
correctAnswer: Extinguishing and/or cooling
Protecting exposures
Extinguishing ground fires before attacking the contents of a tank

structure.description: Describe the spillage considerations for bulk flammable liquids.
options: Water Jets or Monitors onto the spill
Isolating ignition sources
Foam blanket
Storm water drain location for emergency disposal of run off
Containment of run-off
Decontamination and Disposal
correctAnswer: Isolating ignition sources
Foam blanket
Containment of run-off
Decontamination and Disposal

structure.description: Bunded areas, slop over and boil-over are significant hazards at bulk flammable liquid incidents; which of these control measures could be used to manage these hazards?
options: Personnel to only work in bunded area.
All personnel will be trained in the conditions to be encountered and the safe practices required when working at incidents involving bulk flammable liquids
Pre-planning and risk assessment.
Appoint a Welfare Officer
No personnel in the bunded area.
Aim water jets into the centre of the fuel to cool it below ignition temperature
FENZ personnel will be briefed on the plan of action and safety measures.
Appoint a Safety Officer
correctAnswer: All personnel will be trained in the conditions to be encountered and the safe practices required when working at incidents involving bulk flammable liquids
Pre-planning and risk assessment.
No personnel in the bunded area.
FENZ personnel will be briefed on the plan of action and safety measures.
Appoint a Safety Officer

name: H6-1 - Bulk Flammable Gases
intro: This questionnaire verifies knowledge of operational procedures and safety measures for incidents involving bulk flammable gases as defined in Operational Instruction NCI 32.

structure.description: Describe the operational considerations for bulk flammable gases.
options: Approach from upwind where possible
Stabilise and evacuate the inner cordon and other operational areas as required
Consider the use of chemical splash suits
Eliminate all sources of ignition in the inner cordon
Maintain a safe distance of 800m at all times
Identify the gas and its properties and monitor levels of flammability
Use dry powder to dilute the gas in the atmosphere
Notify air traffic control authorities to keep air space clear in vicinity of large leaks
Media statements
correctAnswer: Approach from upwind where possible
Stabilise and evacuate the inner cordon and other operational areas as required
Consider the use of chemical splash suits
Eliminate all sources of ignition in the inner cordon
Identify the gas and its properties and monitor levels of flammability
Notify air traffic control authorities to keep air space clear in vicinity of large leaks
Media statements

structure.description: What is the water application rate to cool gas tanks or pipe-work that have been subjected to direct flame?
options: 2 x GForce branches set at 470L/min
1920 L/m (32 L/s) per m2 in the area of flame impingement.
A ground monitor supplying 800 L/min
360 L/min (6 L/s) per m2 in the area of flame impingement.
structure.correctAnswer: 1920 L/m (32 L/s) per m2 in the area of flame impingement.

structure.description: Describe the control measures used when dealing with the hazards of BLEVE and explosions when controlling fires in bulk flammable gas installations.
options: All personnel will be trained in the conditions to be encountered and the safe practices required when working at incidents involving bulk flammable gases
Lay down a foam blanket surrounding the bulk flammable gas
Pre-planning and risk assessment
FENZ personnel will be briefed on the plan of action and safety measures
Use only the minimum numbers of FENZ personnel needed to conduct operations
Chemical splash suits to be worn if exposure to flammable gas is likely
Establish an inner cordon with a radius of 500m from the fire
Cool tanks and pipe-work, taking care not to freeze up relief valves.
Evacuate all unnecessary personnel, other service personnel and members of the public from inner cordon
Wear structural firefighting uniform and BA
correctAnswer: All personnel will be trained in the conditions to be encountered and the safe practices required when working at incidents involving bulk flammable gases
Pre-planning and risk assessment
FENZ personnel will be briefed on the plan of action and safety measures
Use only the minimum numbers of FENZ personnel needed to conduct operations
Establish an inner cordon with a radius of 500m from the fire
Cool tanks and pipe-work, taking care not to freeze up relief valves.
Evacuate all unnecessary personnel, other service personnel and members of the public from inner cordon
Wear structural firefighting uniform and BA

structure.description: In addition to the above what other control measures should be employed when dealing with the significant hazards of Ignition of gas clouds and cold burns encountered when controlling leaks in bulk flammable gases.
options: Use water protection technique to disperse the gas cloud
Personnel will not enter gas cloud
Consider Gas Tight Suits for operational personnel
Establish inner cordon (consider wind direction)
Awareness of dangers of liquid leaks
correctAnswer: Personnel will not enter gas cloud
Establish inner cordon (consider wind direction)
Awareness of dangers of liquid leaks

name: H6-2 - Portable Gas Cylinders
intro: This questionnaire verifies your knowledge of safe and effective operations at incidents involving portable gas cylinders and pressurized vessels as defined in NCI 33.

structure.description: FENZ Act 2017 Section 39 provides the OIC with the powers of an Enforcement Officer as defined by the Hazardous Substances and New Organisms Act 1996 when managing incidents involving portable gas cylinders.
Which steps should you take when attending an incident involving a leaking cylinder (not involved in fire)?
options: Approach and park downwind and downhill
Evacuate and cordon the affected area
Prevent ignition and monitor the flammability range if possible
Identify the gas and isolate the leak
Keep all doors and windows closed
Liaise with HSTLC or the enforcement officer
Leave the cylinder in place and do not touch it
correctAnswer: Evacuate and cordon the affected area
Prevent ignition and monitor the flammability range if possible
Identify the gas and isolate the leak
Liaise with HSTLC or the enforcement officer

structure.description: If a gas cylinder has been involved in fire, what should be done differently to the standard leaking cylinder procedure?
options: Park upwind and uphill in a SAFE location
Cool the cylinder from a safe position
Remove the cylinder to a safe and secure place
All of the above
correctAnswer: Park upwind and uphill in a SAFE location
Cool the cylinder from a safe position

structure.description: Explain the procedure to safely manage an incident involving an acetylene cylinder involved in a fire or exposed to heat.
options: If it is possible to view cylinder from behind a solid structure: Do not approach the cylinder: Evacuate the area for a 200 metre radius, leave the cylinder in position and apply copious water after the fire is extinguished, check for residual heat after 1 hour. Continue sequence until uniformly cold and remains cold for more than 1 hour. Notify gas supplier to remove; FENZ personnel are not to move it.

If NOT possible to view cylinder from behind a solid structure: Do not approach the cylinder, Evacuate the area for a 200 metre radius. Leave the cylinder in position and apply copious water after the fire is extinguished. Check for residual heat after 1 hour. Continue sequence until uniformly cold and remains cold for more than 1 hour. Notify gas supplier to remove; FENZ personnel are not to move it.
correctAnswer: If it is possible to view cylinder from behind a solid structure: Do not approach the cylinder: Evacuate the area for a 200 metre radius, leave the cylinder in position and apply copious water after the fire is extinguished, check for residual heat after 1 hour. Continue sequence until uniformly cold and remains cold for more than 1 hour. Notify gas supplier to remove; FENZ personnel are not to move it.

If NOT possible to view cylinder from behind a solid structure: Do not approach the cylinder, Evacuate the area for a 200 metre radius. Leave the cylinder in position and apply copious water after the fire is extinguished. Check for residual heat after 1 hour. Continue sequence until uniformly cold and remains cold for more than 1 hour. Notify gas supplier to remove; FENZ personnel are not to move it.

structure.description: What control measures should be put in place in case of BLEVE (Boiling Liquid Expanding Vapour Explosion)?
options: All personnel will be trained in the conditions to be encountered and the safe practices required when working at incidents involving bulk flammable gases
Preplanning and risk assessment with crews briefed on plan of action and safety measures
Use as many personnel as available
Wildfire gear must be worn at all times
Evacuate all unnecessary personnel and public from the area and establish an inner cordon
Cool cylinders from a protected position
Approach the cylinders with a protective water spray
Take care not to freeze up relief valves if cooling water is applied
correctAnswer: All personnel will be trained in the conditions to be encountered and the safe practices required when working at incidents involving bulk flammable gases
Preplanning and risk assessment with crews briefed on plan of action and safety measures
Evacuate all unnecessary personnel and public from the area and establish an inner cordon
Cool cylinders from a protected position
Take care not to freeze up relief valves if cooling water is applied

structure.description: In addition to the standard precautions, what control measures should be taken when dealing with gas clouds?
options: Use a gas detector in the centre of the cloud to check for possibility of ignition
No personnel to enter the gas cloud
Maintain awareness of the dangers of leaking pressurised gas
Use positive pressure ventilation to blow the cloud away
correctAnswer: No personnel to enter the gas cloud
Maintain awareness of the dangers of leaking pressurised gas

name: H7-1 - Clandestine Laboratories
intro: This questionnaire verifies your knowledge of the safety procedures and liaison requirements for incidents involving clandestine drug laboratories as defined in NCI 14

structure.description: What are the three significant hazards identified in Clandestine Laboratories?
options: Hazardous Chemicals
Traffic
Booby Traps
Hostile Civilians
Smoke and heat
Wild animals
correctAnswer: Hazardous Chemicals
Booby Traps
Hostile Civilians

structure.description: Which agency is the lead agency at a clandestine laboratory incident?
options: Fire and Emergency New Zealand
New Zealand Police
Ambulance Service
Environmental Agency

structure.description: What must the first three control measures be at a suspected clandestine laboratory incident?
options: Check that laboratory is currently operational
Withdraw
Secure Premises
Remove apparatus to a safe place
Notify Comms/Police
correctAnswer: Withdraw
Secure Premises
Notify Comms/Police

structure.description: Which of these signs OUTSIDE a building may indicate a clandestine laboratory is inside the building?
options: Chemical odours
Loud music
Opaque windows / Bars on windows
High occupancy of building
Discarded waste packaging
Multiple vehicles and vans parked outside
High security measures - Cameras, barbed wire fence, Guard dogs
correctAnswer: Chemical odours
Opaque windows / Bars on windows
Discarded waste packaging
Multiple vehicles and vans parked outside
High security measures - Cameras, barbed wire fence, Guard dogs

structure.description: Which of these signs INSIDE a building might indicate a clandestine laboratory?
options: Chemical smell
Heavy layer of smoke
Heavy orange staining of the interior
Laboratory glassware
Acetylene cylinders
Bunsen Burners / LPG cylinders
Hot Plates
Lithium batteries / Bulk chemical containers.
Large amounts of food in storage
correctAnswer: Chemical smell
Heavy orange staining of the interior
Laboratory glassware
Bunsen Burners / LPG cylinders
Hot Plates
Lithium batteries / Bulk chemical containers.

structure.description: Once firefighters have withdrawn, who gives permission for firefighting to commence?
options: The Chief Fire Officer / OIC
Fire Comms
New Zealand Police
Environmental Agency

name: IS1 - Operational Safety
intro: This form verifies your understanding of the safety and health responsibilities of personnel regarding themselves and others at incidents as defined in NCI 1. Completion is required for OSM compliance.

structure.description: Which of these must the OIC Crew do to ensure the safety and effectiveness of the firefighting crew?
options: Use the nominal role tally procedure and BA entry control procedures.
Follow operational procedures
Assist with operational tasks
Evaluate priorities, give direction and maintain control.
Establish an incident management structure
Populate the Entry Control Board
Monitor progress as it relates to their area of operations
Operate the Main Pump
correctAnswer: Use the nominal role tally procedure and BA entry control procedures.
Follow operational procedures
Evaluate priorities, give direction and maintain control.
Establish an incident management structure
Monitor progress as it relates to their area of operations

structure.description: What must any FENZ personnel do if they identify a hazard?
options: Note the hazard for later reference during debrief
Bring the hazard to the attention of their OIC or the OIC Fire.
Record the hazard on the Entry Control Board
structure.correctAnswer: Bring the hazard to the attention of their OIC or the OIC Fire.

structure.description: Civilian and other agency personnel can be used to assist with FENZ operations as long as they have been made aware of all hazards, given clear instructions regarding the management of the hazards and briefed on the role they will be undertaking.
Who is responsible for ensuring the crew are wearing seatbelts when their appliance is mobile?
options: The driver
The individual
The Safety Officer
The OIC

structure.description: Who is responsible for specifying the appropriate type of PPE for the incident being attended?
options: The individual
The driver
The OIC
The Safety Officer

structure.description: BA will be worn by all personnel working in a contaminated atmosphere or any atmosphere suspected of being contaminated.
How many persons must be committed operationally at an incident for a safety officer to be appointed?
options: More than 10
More than 12
More than 16
More than 3 crews

structure.description: Which of these other situations must also have a Safety Officer appointed?
options: Hazardous substances are involved and a Hot Zone is established
More than 2 Entry Control Points have been set up
Live fire training is being undertaken.
Operating in unusual or unfamiliar circumstances.
Whenever FENZ is not the lead agency and a Safety Officer is required for FENZ operations.
For incidents involving Aerial appliances
correctAnswer: Hazardous substances are involved and a Hot Zone is established
Live fire training is being undertaken.
Operating in unusual or unfamiliar circumstances.
Whenever FENZ is not the lead agency and a Safety Officer is required for FENZ operations.

structure.description: What is the emergency evacuation signal?
options: Mayday message
Continuous operation of all vehicle sirens
Operation of the Distress Signal Unit
Whistles
structure.correctAnswer: Continuous operation of all vehicle sirens

structure.description: What must all personnel do on hearing the emergency evacuation signal?
options: Shut down firefighting deliveries at the nozzle.
Carry out a quick search for personnel or patients
Withdraw to a place of safety.
Recover any equipment that might get lost or damaged
Uplift BA tallies from the Entry Control Officer and return to their appliance.
correctAnswer: Shut down firefighting deliveries at the nozzle.
Withdraw to a place of safety.
Uplift BA tallies from the Entry Control Officer and return to their appliance.

structure.description: What must the OIC do on hearing the emergency evacuation signal?
options: Uplift nominal roll tallies and conduct a head count.
Send in relief team to continue operations
Advise the OIC Fire of the result.
correctAnswer: Uplift nominal roll tallies and conduct a head count.
Advise the OIC Fire of the result.

structure.description: At hazardous materials incidents the OIC should consider appointing a Hazard Control Officer to assist with the management of the incident.
At the end of the incident the person responsible for the building should be briefed on any remaining hazards before FENZ relinquishes responsibility of the site.
Significant Hazard Exposure Protocols must be followed if a significant health hazard or potentially significant health hazard is identified.

name: IS3 - Working Near Roadways
intro: This questionnaire verifies your understanding of safe practices when operating on or near roadways as defined in IS3 POP and IS3 SOP. These procedures ensure the safety of personnel and the public during incident-related activities.

structure.description: What factors must the driver of an appliance consider when operating on roadways?
options: Park next to the nearest fire hydrant
Park to create a safe working environment or park off the road.
Allow space and/or access for other emergency vehicles
Park in the middle of the road and leave the sirens operating
Leave the beacons on
Drive off the roadway at the earliest opportunity to reduce traffic.
Adjust the headlights to meet the conditions at the scene, considering time of day, light levels, glare hazard for other drivers
correctAnswer: Park to create a safe working environment or park off the road.
Allow space and/or access for other emergency vehicles
Leave the beacons on
Adjust the headlights to meet the conditions at the scene, considering time of day, light levels, glare hazard for other drivers

structure.description: What must all FENZ personnel do in relation to crew safety when working on roadways?
options: Don approved reflective clothing
Arrange for an alternative route for traffic to avoid the incident
Exit vehicles from the safe side if possible
Wear flashing lights on jerkins so that you are always visible to other people
correctAnswer: Don approved reflective clothing
Exit vehicles from the safe side if possible

structure.description: What factors does the OIC Fire have to consider when creating and maintaining a safe working environment?
options: Close the road if two-way traffic cannot be achieved
Request police to guide traffic
Ask members of the public to use their cars to create a barricade
correctAnswer: Close the road if two-way traffic cannot be achieved
Request police to guide traffic

structure.description: What safety considerations does the OIC have to ensure before departing the scene?
options: Made safe by FENZ personnel
Left as it was found for police investigation
Handed over to another agency or authority to be made safe
correctAnswer: Made safe by FENZ personnel
Handed over to another agency or authority to be made safe

name: IS4 - Working Near Electrical Hazards
intro: This questionnaire verifies your knowledge of the safety procedures for incidents involving electrical hazards as defined in NCI 12 and the EEA Guide to Electrical Network Safety.

structure.description: Which of these risks may need to be considered when working near electrical hazards?
options: Fallen wires
Rescues in or around live electrical hazards
Ground level transformers, switch gear and kiosks
Earthquakes and tsunamis
Pole fires, substation fires and explosions
Underground installations
Polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs)
Power stations
Drowning or trapped beneath water
correctAnswer: Fallen wires
Rescues in or around live electrical hazards
Ground level transformers, switch gear and kiosks
Pole fires, substation fires and explosions
Underground installations
Polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs)
Power stations

structure.description: Which of these hazards are associated with working near electricity?
options: Electrocution
Hydrochloric acid
Oil
Gases from fixed installations
Asphyxiation
correctAnswer: Electrocution
Oil
Gases from fixed installations

structure.description: All personnel should be trained in the risks to be encountered and safe practices when working with electrical hazards and crew(s) briefed on plan of action and safety measures.
Electricity supply should NOT be isolated when crew are working nearby.
Treat all equipment/installations as live until certified as not live by power company engineer and only carry out rescues only with full agreement of power company engineer.
If an electrical storm is imminent, withdraw to a safe distance from transmission structures to avoid lightning strikes.
FENZ ladders and other long equipment are safe to use alongside electrical equipment or overhead lines.
The OIC should carry out which control measures?
options: Contact and liaise with power company representatives
Keep personnel directly involved to a minimum
Ensure that crews work together within a 4m cordon of the electric equipment.
Ensure that crews wear full PPE and BA.
Direct deliveries onto electrical equipment at the earliest opportunity.
correctAnswer: Contact and liaise with power company representatives
Keep personnel directly involved to a minimum
Ensure that crews wear full PPE and BA.

structure.description: All personnel should be trained in safe manual handling techniques.

name: IS9 - Working Near Civil Disturbances
intro: This questionnaire verifies your knowledge of safe and effective operations at incidents where crowd behaviour places personnel and operations at risk, as defined in NCI 29. FENZ personnel must maintain neutrality and prioritize the protection of life and property.

structure.description: Which other organisation(s) should be consulted when attending an incident involving a civil disturbance?
options: Victim Support
Local District Council
New Zealand Police
Fire and Emergency - On Call Executive

structure.description: Which of the following should be included in Approved Local Procedures for attending a civil disturbance?
options: The pre-determined response
Liaison with the police and other emergency services
Water supplies for crowd dispersal
Hostile crowd behaviour / Riots / Protest marches
Any disturbance that develops while Fire and Emergency NZ personnel are attending an incident
Procedures for when working alone
Rescue and protection of persons and property from fire
How to restrain a hostile member of public
Safety of FENZ personnel and the security of fire stations
Expected weather conditions
correctAnswer: The pre-determined response
Liaison with the police and other emergency services
Hostile crowd behaviour / Riots / Protest marches
Any disturbance that develops while Fire and Emergency NZ personnel are attending an incident
Rescue and protection of persons and property from fire
Safety of FENZ personnel and the security of fire stations

structure.description: The role of Fire and Emergency NZ at civil disturbance incidents is to protect life and property, NOT to support the police in quelling riots or enforcing order.
During the readiness or pre-planning phase, what considerations should FENZ and NZ Police address?
options: Containment areas for hostile members of the public
Foster understanding of each other's roles and methods of operation
Agree on local procedures
How many fire crews might be available for crowd dispersal.
Identify potential points of tension in the community
Water supplies for use on protesters
correctAnswer: Foster understanding of each other's roles and methods of operation
Agree on local procedures
Identify potential points of tension in the community

structure.description: When developing predetermined attendance protocols, what are the four criteria required when responding?
options: Use the minimum number of appliances for the initial response
Determine safe and secure response routes
Discuss the fastest way to get there under lights and sirens
Do not use flashing lights and sirens
What riot gear fire-fighters are to wear when responding
Liaise with NZ Police to determine whether a police escort is necessary
correctAnswer: Use the minimum number of appliances for the initial response
Determine safe and secure response routes
Do not use flashing lights and sirens
Liaise with NZ Police to determine whether a police escort is necessary

structure.description: What actions need to be taken when a disturbance develops at an incident that Fire and Emergency NZ personnel are attending?
options: Prepare monitor for crowd dispersal
Establish the whereabouts of all personnel
Withdraw to a safe place
Call station for additional crews
Advise ComCen
Liaise with NZ Police
correctAnswer: Establish the whereabouts of all personnel
Withdraw to a safe place
Advise ComCen
Liaise with NZ Police

structure.description: What PPE should Fire and Emergency NZ personnel wear when in attendance at civil disturbances?
options: Chemical Splash Suits and BA
Level 1s as they allow easier movement
Structural firefighting uniform at all times, with visors down.
structure.correctAnswer: Structural firefighting uniform at all times, with visors down.

structure.description: What three considerations should be put in place, in regards to appliances and firefighting, to enable a quick withdrawal from an incident should the situation deteriorate?
options: Park appliances with the driver remaining in the driver's seat with the engine running
Only use appliance Hose Reels
Use personal lines so that crew don't become separated
Do not use appliance Hose Reels
Use delivery hose from hydrants where the water pressure is sufficient.
correctAnswer: Park appliances with the driver remaining in the driver's seat with the engine running
Do not use appliance Hose Reels
Use delivery hose from hydrants where the water pressure is sufficient.

structure.description: Can operational support staff be used for crowd control duties if requested by OIC Police?
options: If they are available and wearing adequate PPE
If clearance is given by the CFO
No

structure.description: Select the significant hazards that may be faced by crews, both responding to and at, civil disturbance incidents.
options: Backdraught or flashover
Missiles thrown at vehicles
Vehicles hitting barricades
Clandestine Laboratories (Clan Labs)
Vehicles being hi-jacked
Fire bombs
Physical attack
correctAnswer: Missiles thrown at vehicles
Vehicles hitting barricades
Vehicles being hi-jacked
Fire bombs
Physical attack
